Award.AwardTitle: NSF INCLUDES PLANNING GRANT: Women in a Network of Discovery (WIND)

Division.LongName: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

Award.AbstractNarration: NSF INCLUDES Planning Grants Project - Women in a Network of Discovery (WIND)<br/><br/>This NSF INCLUDES planning grant is funded by NSF Inclusion across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science (NSF INCLUDES), a comprehensive national initiative to enhance U.S. leadership in discoveries and innovations by focusing on diversity, inclusion, and broadening participation in STEM at scale. The goal of this planning grant is to increase the number of women engineers from minority, low-income, and first-generation groups. The U.S. needs more women engineers to contribute to economic and national security and strengthen engineering research, commercialization, and product development through inclusive innovation. The vibrancy of inclusive innovation will positively impact academic, business, and national security competitiveness.<br/><br/>The WIND approach is research-based and includes the Kettering Foundationâ€™s Learning Exchanges Model, which encourages collaborative change within communities through the participation of all stakeholders in visioning, asset mapping, and decision making. The planning grant will be used to convene partners with a range of expertise and experience to build a pathway to engineering for women in North Carolina, particularly women from underrepresented groups. Initial partners include Alamance-Burlington School System (K-12), Alamance Community College (Associate Degree), and Elon University and North Carolina State University (Bachelor's Degree). The WIND project exemplifies the partnerships element of collaborative infrastructure building and efforts will be directed to developing a model and network that are scalable to the state of North Carolina and the Nation.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award Number: 2040841

Project Title:  Women in a Network of Discovery (WIND)

Funding Opportunity: NSF 19-600 Inclusion Across the Nation of Communities of Learners of Underrepresented Discoverers in Engineering and Science (NSF INCLUDES)
Project Grant Period: 12/01/2020 - 11/30/2022

The goal of Women in a Network of Discovery (WIND) was to create a plan and network to get more Alamance County girl students interested in engineering careers. To accomplish this, WIND built a partnership of educational institutions from kindergarten to bachelor's degrees, including Alamance Community College, Alamance Burlington School System, Elon University, and North Carolina State University. The project conducted both primary and secondary research about barriers preventing girls from choosing engineering within Alamance County and created strategies for addressing the barriers. The resulting insights and recommendations have broad implications for increasing the engineering workforce.

WIND activities included creating an Asset Map, a literature review, and convening focus groups, public forums, and an Advisory Committee. To discover the existing Engineering ecosystem within the County, the WIND team created an Asset Map of relevant STEM/engineering staff and organizations in Alamance County. Few engineering programs existed:  10% of schools had engineering programs in K-5th, none in 6th-8th grades, and 22% in high schools. The lack of programs in junior high points to a potential problem, later verified through interviews, about the lack of engineering programs in the critical transition period from elementary to high school. To complement this research, WIND staff reviewed past research literature on gender barriers to engineering careers. All WIND documents are available at the WIND website (https://bit.ly/stemmingthetide).

WIND conducted four focus groups:  elementary school girls, middle school girls, high school women, and parents/teachers. Then WIND held two public forums, one in person and one online, for anyone wishing to participate. 

Several themes emerged from the focus groups:  1) Opportunities already exist for engineering education. Area colleges, universities, and businesses offer engineering programs to 3-12 students. These opportunities are offered outside school hours through summer camps and after-school programs.  However, students from underrepresented communities disproportionately do not attend these camps. Barriers such as affordability, transportation, and knowledge about the programs/lack of family resources contribute to the absence of diversity among participants; 2) Professional development opportunities are needed to inform educators about STEM programs. Educators participating in STEM-specific professional development programs are better informed about STEM and more confident when motivating students from underrepresented communities.  Informed educators can recognize and tap into girls' interests and help the development of their engineering identity; 3) There is a lack of understanding/limited knowledge about Engineering Careers. Participants shared concerns about the schools' capacity to create engineering clubs and other student career opportunities. As a result, students are not well informed about engineering careers. Additionally, parents lack understanding about engineering careers, which contributes to students' lack of understanding; and 4) There is a lack of knowledge of industry trends and workforce needs. Alamance County moved from textiles to engineering-dominant manufacturing, and the existing workforce lacks training in the new technologies.

The focus groups revealed a lack of knowledge about the job tasks an engineer completes on a daily basis. An unclear understanding of engineering /professional mentors and their purpose was also shared among all groups, even though mentoring is a critical resource for career exploration. The idea of "perfectionism" and the stereotype that engineering was extremely difficult was common among elementary and middle school focus groups. "Methodical" described engineers mentioned in parent and teacher focus groups. All student groups enjoyed problem-solving, creativity, and socializing/collaboration, which could be tapped for effective engineering education programs. "Intimidation" was a feeling mentioned in the parent/teacher focus group. Feeling intimidated by engineering makes it difficult for parents to encourage and motivate their daughters. A few parents have engineers in their network but are still unsure about specific duties and responsibilities. As a result, they are unable to explain engineering to their daughters.

WIND convened an advisory group of educators, business people, and county government staff to get further feedback on resources and strategies. The advisory committee created a strategic plan for WIND, which re-enforced previous recommendations from other sources:  1) Educate girls and their families on engineering as an education and career field; 2) Define an engineering exposure and extra-curricular interest system for grades 3-12 girls in Alamance County, which includes hands-on experiences; 3) Enable an easily accessible online interface/platform to allow girls and their parents to find programs; 4) Enable effective non-digital communications to allow girls and their parents to find programs; 5) Educate girls and their parents on college readiness activities needed to pursue a higher education degree in an engineering field; 6) Encourage Alamance County community support and engagement; and 7) Establish a WIND structure that provides ongoing organizational support and funding sources to sustain and expand the engineering education support system.
